reviewText: First off, this disc will only play in 3D, and it's only 720p, this is one reason why I deducted 1 star.In spite of it only being 720p, the scenes on the soccer/football fields are pretty amazing.  The extra inserted interview footage, not so much.  the interview footage is very soft and not quite too sharp, where as the footage on the fields is amazingly sharp.This movie is simply a documentary of the World Cup playoffs in South Africa.  It points out how having the tournament in S. Africa has given pride to the nation as a whole, and brought people of all races in Africa together.Mainly, however, it highlights many of the (most important) games of the FIFA 2010 World Cup series.  I am by no means a sports fan, but I found this BD very entertaining.  The footage shot during the games at times makes you feel like your right in the middle of the action.  For the most part, the 3D was shot very well, except for a few brief instances of mis-synch between left and right images, and what appears to be a brief instances where the stereo seems inverted.  There's not too much of this, however, but this is the other reason I deducted one star.The interviews and other supplementary inserted footage at times appears to be rather flat, with very little depth, especially the outside shots of the stadiums, but I assume that is due to the zoom factor from a long distance.  The interviews were shot rather close, and those are almost flat as well.However, the game footage is awesome, which is why I bought the BD in the first place.  I had seen a short clip of some of the action in 3D which looked really nice, and when I saw the title up for pre-oreder, I jumped on it.It was nice to see how they take you through the games, highlighting the important goals, wins and losses.  I really felt bad when the last African nation in the series, Ghana, lost.  Being right in the middle of it made it feel more real for me.Overall, the film was very well made, and in spite of being only 720p resolution, looks very good.  There was practically no ghosting to speak of, at least on my 42" Panasonic Plasma screen.When I inserted the disc, and started the movie, it immediately displayed in 3D, I didn't have to chage the setting on the TV.  The TV and BluRay player have what Panasonic calls VieraLink, which lets the devices communicate with each other when connected via HDMI.  I have the BluRay player set to always play 3D  titles in 3D, so I don't know if this is why I didn't have to set the TV myself.At any rate, this was a very entertaining look at something I virtually ignored while it was happening, the FIFA 2010 World Cup.  I will watch it again, at some point, and I would reccomment this title to the folks out there with 3d TV's that are hungry for content.  It's a live action film, as opposed to the mostly CGI 3D movies that have been made in the last few years, so this is another bonus -- getting to see real humans in 3D.
summary: Overall excellent title with a flew flaws
Title: N/A

reviewText: This disc has mostly fantastic looking 3D and is among the best released on BD so far.  The video from the WC highlights has first rate sports real life 3D.  The interviews that were conducted and inserted into this film are mostly out of focus and do not look as good as the football highlights.  But the highlights are the important part and the 3D on this disc looks better than the original broadcast.I watched most of the WC games and this was a fun recap.
Title: N/A

reviewText: For a 3D Blu-ray done at 720p, this title is done REALLY, REALLY, REALLY well!!! Shot in true 3D footage (none of that fake fill in footage we tolerate now), it puts you so deep in the game, you are amazed at how involved you are. That alone gives this title a five star review. Why it is knocked down to 3? Sony cheated the US consumers. This BD release was to promote the Sony 3D Blu-ray market entry. The campaign was rigorous in the US. Sony pushed Blu-Ray adoption, pushing 3D and pushing 4K. So why release a title such as this and completely ignore the entire US inclusion in one of the greatest World Cups we've had. The US vs England match was hyped and talked about with major enthusiasm. They had not met seen each other in a match in 60 years, and for Sony to ignore it was completely disrespectful. The US v Ghana game was epic in the Round of 16! Again...we should have been considered. The footage was there...IN 3D, just edited out. They even featured Landon Donovan in the menu as an even bigger slap in the face. Overall...I am happy that I purchased it. It put me back in the Summer of 2010. I just needed so much more.
summary: ALMOST everything you could want on this AMAZING FIFA Event!
Title: N/A

reviewText: My ratings are based mainly on the QUALITY OF THE 3D, not the video content.I counted 9 out of screen effects, 6 that extend about 10% of the way, from the screen to the viewer and another 3 OOS effects around 20%, nothing special about them.No real complaints about the in screen 3D. Most of the footage is clear and excess parallax was only noticeable 2 times.*** Colorful, Clear in screen 3D, Great for soccer fans ****** This is NOT a movie to show off OOS effects with ***MY 3D RATING = GOOD (poor, fair, good, very good, excellent)Note: As far as the percentages go, everyone's eyes are different. What I see at 25% you may see at 15% or 35%. To fully realize how far something is out of the screen for you, pause on an effect and direct a partner with an extended finger to the tip of what you are seeing. You may be surprised.Click on `See all my reviews' for the lowdown on other 3Ds
Title: N/A

reviewText: After being among the various ethnic crowds who were listening and/or generatingthe unforgettable and irritable buzz of noises at the 2010 Fifa World Cup;  Imust praise "Sony Pictures Home Entertainament Inc." for using a nice music theme tocover up the unofficial soundtrack ie. the relentless drone of the vuvuzelas (theear-splitting din of the traditional South African stadium horns) during soccer (football)matches, which reached more than 125 decibels.  The in-depth 3D effects were superbwhen considering that soccer (football) is in fact a long distance visual capture elementfrom our eyes; however, the out-of-the screen 3D efffects were somewhat minimal andaverage, as I did expect to have the balls coming out of the screen and hit me; one morething, "Sony's Disc distributors" could had at least placed the picture of the "World Cup"or even the "3D effect at the intro of the film" on the disc itself rather than selling thedisc as it is (blank and unattractive).Overall, this 3D Blu-ray is a MUST for 3D Lovers' collections because this 2010 eventis  bygone and hence is to be preserved as an heirloom no matter how bad it seems tosome people.  I do recommend that you torpedo yourself to Amazon.com and get a copybefore it runs out.
summary: 2010 Fifa World Cup Film 3D Review By Reggun
Title: N/A
